speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo feels optimistic because his dreams suggest good news is coming; his heart feels light and his mood is elevated. He dreamed Juliet kissed him back to life, making him feel like an emperor, and reflects that even dreams of love are joyful compared to real love. This hopeful mood sharply contrasts with the tragic news to come.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar says Juliet is well in spirit but her body lies in the Capulet tomb; he saw her buried and rode quickly to tell Romeo, apologizing for the bad news since Romeo asked him to report.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo immediately resolves to defy fate, asking for ink, paper, and post-horses to leave for Verona tonight, showing his rash decision to join Juliet in death.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar urges patience, noting Romeo’s pale and wild appearance suggests some disaster is imminent.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses Balthasar’s concern, insists he is mistaken, and repeats his order to get horses, asking again about letters from the Friar.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar simply says he has no letters from the Friar.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says it doesn’t matter and sends Balthasar to hire horses, saying he will follow soon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo declares he will kill himself to lie with Juliet tonight, then recalls an apothecary he saw recently who looked poor and desperate, with a shop full of strange items, and thought then that such a man would sell poison despite the law.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo notes that his earlier observation foreshadowed his current need, and he identifies the apothecary’s shut shop, calling out to him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo offers forty ducats for a fast-acting poison that will spread through the veins and kill as quickly as a cannon firing.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells the apothecary that since he is already suffering and the world’s laws don’t help him, he should break the law and take the money.
